ground_truth: The camera races with the train along the river's edge, the reflected sun glimmering on the windows. The sun is high and the train is stopped by the river. We see an English clergyman from the Second Class coaches, dipping a toe cautiously into the water, children of some British enlisted soldiers wading, splashing, faces alight with fun. Across the river down from the Third Class coaches, a small group of Indian women is squatted by the river's edge, washing clothes. Some carry infants on their backs, and some small children stand near them. Their ritual of washing goes on, but they are all watching the passengers of the train. Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class passengers. Charlie, his trousers rolled up, plays a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian boy. Gandhi is holding a large white head cloth which he is soaking in the water, but his eyes have been arrested by the sight of the women across the river. Their bodies are skin and bone. The clothes they wear, which looked normal from the distance, are rags - literally, shredded rags, one hung on another. Gandhi stares for a moment, a long beat. Climbing green hills - a totally different terrain - and again we intercut, this time the train climbing: a boy and buffalo running a huge, crude grinding wheel, train climbing; farmers in terraced fields, train climbing faster and faster. Gandhi is leaning out of a window in a Third Class coach. Ahead of him, other passengers are looking too; some have jumped down. As they come clear, they can see that a military train of an engine and two cars has been derailed ahead of them. A small troop of cavalry is coming slowly along the line of Gandhi's train toward them. They are British, and their troop leader is viciously angry. Nehru takes an iced drink from a servant, and Nehru shakes his head wistfully. The train passes the camera to the Third Class section, which seems besieged by humanity. People cling to the outside of each door and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches. Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the outside of the coach, hanging on through the door, and both enjoying it immensely. Ba, inside the jammed coach, finds it very unfunny. She has a grip on one of Gandhi's arms. The camera has been moving in; now it jumps to Jinnah in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience. And the audience cheers him. Newspaper cameramen crowded around the platform photograph him. Patel comes forward from the back of the platform, clapping.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The camera dashes with the locomotive along the river's brink, the mirrored sun shimmering on the panes. The sun is elevated and the train is halted by the river. We observe an English minister from the Second Class carriages, dipping a toe cautiously into the water, offspring of some British enlisted servicemen wading, splashing, faces aglow with amusement. Across the river down from the Third Class carriages, a small cluster of Indian women is crouched by the river's brink, laundering garments. Some carry infants on their backs, and some small youngsters stand near them. Their ritual of laundering persists, but they are all observing the travelers of the train. Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class travelers. Charlie, his trousers rolled up, engages in a tentative splashing pastime with a skinny little Indian lad. Gandhi is grasping a large white head cloth which he is immersing in the water, but his eyes have been captivated by the sight of the women across the river. Their bodies are skin and bone. The garments they wear, which appeared ordinary from the distance, are tatters - literally, shredded tatters, one hung on another. Gandhi gazes for a moment, a prolonged pause. Climbing verdant hills - a completely different landscape - and again we intercut, this time the train ascending: a lad and buffalo operating a huge, crude milling wheel, train ascending; farmers in terraced fields, train ascending quicker and quicker. Gandhi is leaning out of a pane in a Third Class carriage. Ahead of him, other travelers are observing too; some have leaped down. As they come clear, they can perceive that a military locomotive of an engine and two cars has been derailed ahead of them. A small troop of cavalry is approaching slowly along the line of Gandhi's train toward them. They are British, and their troop leader is fiercely irate. Nehru takes an iced beverage from a servant, and Nehru shakes his head wistfully. The train traverses the camera to the Third Class section, which seems besieged by humanity. People cling to the exterior of each door and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two carriages. Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the exterior of the carriage, gripping through the door, and both enjoying it enormously. Ba, inside the jammed carriage, finds it very unfunny. She has a grip on one of Gandhi's arms. The camera has been moving in; now it leaps to Jinnah in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervent delivery on the audience. And the audience acclaims him. Newspaper photographers crowded around the platform capture him. Patel advances from the rear of the platform, applauding.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The train is raced with by the camera along the river's edge, with the reflected sun glimmering on the windows. The sun is high and it stops the train by the river. An English clergyman is seen by us from the Second Class coaches, his toe dipped cautiously into the water, splashing children of some British enlisted soldiers, their faces alight with fun. Across the river, down from the Third Class coaches, a small group of Indian women squats by the river's edge, and clothes are washed by them. Infants are carried on their backs by some, and some small children stand near them. Their ritual of washing goes on, but the passengers of the train are watched by them all. Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class passengers. A tentative splashing game is played by Charlie, his trousers rolled up, with a skinny little Indian boy. A large white head cloth is held by Gandhi, which he soaks in the water, but the sight of the women across the river arrests his eyes. Their bodies are skin and bone. The clothes they wear, which looked normal from a distance, are rags - literally, shredded rags, hung one on another. Gandhi stares for a moment, a long beat. Green hills are climbed - a totally different terrain - and this time we intercut, with the train climbing: a huge, crude grinding wheel is run by a boy and buffalo, train climbing; farmers work in terraced fields, and the train is climbed faster and faster. A window in a Third Class coach is leaned out of by Gandhi. Ahead of him, other passengers look too; some have jumped down. As they come clear, they can see that a military train of an engine and two cars has derailed ahead of them. A small troop of cavalry comes slowly along the line of Gandhi's train toward them. They are British, and their troop leader shows vicious anger. An iced drink is taken by Nehru from a servant, and he shakes his head wistfully. The train is passed by the camera to the Third Class section, besieged by humanity. The outside of each door is clung to by people and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches. The outside of the coach is ridden on by Gandhi and Charlie, who hang on through the door, both enjoying it immensely. Ba, inside the jammed coach, finds it very unfunny. One of Gandhi's arms is gripped by her. The camera has been moving in; now Jinnah is jumped to in a close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience. And cheers are given by the audience to him. Newspaper cameramen crowd around the platform and photograph him. The back of the platform is approached by Patel, clapping.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The camera races alongside the train by the river, sunlight glinting off windows. With the sun high, the train stops. An English clergyman from Second Class dips a toe in the water, as British soldiers’ children wade and splash, joyful. Across the river from Third Class coaches, Indian women squat, washing clothes, some with infants on their backs, others with small children nearby. Though working, they watch the train passengers. Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among Third Class passengers. Charlie, trousers rolled up, splashes with a skinny Indian boy. Gandhi soaks a white head cloth in the river, but his gaze is fixed on the women. They are emaciated, their clothes mere rags. He stares, deeply affected. The scene shifts to green hills and a train climbing: a boy and buffalo run a crude grinding wheel; farmers work terraced fields; the train speeds upward. Gandhi leans from a Third Class window. Others peer ahead or have jumped off. A derailed military train lies ahead. British cavalry approaches; their leader is furious. Nehru sips an iced drink and shakes his head wistfully. The train rolls past, Third Class packed—people cling to doors and sit atop coaches. Gandhi and Charlie hang outside, enjoying it, while Ba, inside, grips Gandhi’s arm, unimpressed. The camera zooms in on Jinnah mid-speech, intercut with the crowd’s excited reaction. Cheering erupts. Cameramen swarm the platform. Patel steps forward clapping.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The camera races with the train along the river, the sun glimmering on windows. The train stops by the river. An English clergyman dips a toe in the water; British soldiers' children wade and splash. Across the river, Indian women wash clothes, some with infants, watching the passengers. Gandhi, with Ba and Charlie, is among the Third Class passengers. Charlie splashes with a boy; Gandhi soaks a head cloth, noticing the women's rags. The train climbs hills, intercut with a boy and buffalo at a grinding wheel and farmers in fields. Gandhi leans out a Third Class window. Passengers see a derailed military train ahead. A British cavalry troop approaches, their leader angry. Nehru takes an iced drink, shaking his head. The train passes, crowded with people clinging to doors and roofs. Gandhi and Charlie hang on outside, enjoying it; Ba inside finds it unfunny, gripping Gandhi's arm. The camera moves to Jinnah's fervid speech, the audience cheers, and newspaper cameramen photograph him. Patel claps from the platform's back.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The camera swiftly races alongside the train as it travels along the edge of the river, capturing the sun's reflection glimmering brightly on the train's windows. The sun is positioned high in the sky, casting its warm light, and the train has come to a halt by the riverbank. From the Second Class coaches, we observe an English clergyman, who is cautiously dipping a toe into the water, while children of some British enlisted soldiers are wading and splashing around, their faces alight with pure joy and fun. Across the river, a little downstream from the Third Class coaches, a small group of Indian women is squatted by the river's edge, engaged in the task of washing clothes. Some of these women carry infants securely on their backs, while a few small children stand nearby, observing. Although their ritual of washing continues, their attention is drawn to the passengers of the train. Among the Third Class passengers, Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie. Charlie, with his trousers rolled up, is engaged in a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian boy. Gandhi, meanwhile, is holding a large white head cloth, which he is soaking in the water, but his eyes are captivated by the sight of the women across the river. Their bodies are emaciated, skin and bone. The clothes they wear, which appeared normal from a distance, are actually rags—literally, shredded rags, layered one over another. Gandhi stares for a moment, a long, contemplative beat. The scene shifts to climbing green hills—a completely different terrain—and once again, we intercut, this time with the train climbing: a boy and buffalo are running a huge, crude grinding wheel, the train climbing; farmers are working in terraced fields, the train climbing faster and faster. Gandhi is leaning out of a window in a Third Class coach. Ahead of him, other passengers are also looking out; some have even jumped down. As they come into view, they can see that a military train, consisting of an engine and two cars, has been derailed ahead of them. A small troop of cavalry is slowly making its way along the line of Gandhi's train toward them. They are British, and their troop leader is visibly and viciously angry. Nehru takes an iced drink from a servant, and he shakes his head wistfully. The train passes the camera, moving to the Third Class section, which appears to be besieged by humanity. People cling to the outside of each door, and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches. Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the outside of the coach, hanging on through the door, and both are enjoying the experience immensely. Ba, inside the jam-packed coach, finds it very unfunny. She maintains a firm grip on one of Gandhi's arms. The camera has been moving in; now it jumps to Jinnah in a close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience. The audience responds with cheers. Newspaper cameramen, crowded around the platform, photograph him. Patel comes forward from the back of the platform, clapping enthusiastically.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
As the camera swiftly races along the edge of the shimmering river, it closely follows the train in motion, capturing the sunlight that dances and glimmers brightly on the polished windows of the train cars. The sun, positioned high above in the vast sky, casts its generous, warm light upon the scene below. The train finds itself coming to a halt right by the tranquil riverbank. From the open windows of the Second Class coaches, we observe the figure of an English clergyman, who is cautiously dipping his toe into the cool water, as children of some British enlisted soldiers happily wade and splash around, their faces illuminated with expressions of pure joy and unrestrained fun.

A little downstream, on the opposite side of the river from the Third Class coaches, there is a small group of Indian women. They are squatted by the river's edge, engrossed in the rhythmic task of washing clothes. Some of these diligent women are seen carrying infants securely on their backs, while a few small children stand nearby, watching with curiosity. Although their methodical ritual of washing continues, their attention intermittently shifts to the intriguing sight of the passengers alighting from the train. Among these Third Class passengers, we see Gandhi standing with Ba and Charlie. Charlie, with his trousers playfully rolled up, is engaged in a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian boy. Gandhi, on the other hand, is holding a large white head cloth, soaking it in the water, though his eyes are captivated by the sight of the women across the river. Their bodies appear emaciated, mere skin and bone. The clothes they wear, which seemed quite normal from a distance, reveal themselves to be mere rags—literally, tattered shreds layered one over another. Gandhi finds himself staring for a moment, lost in a long, contemplative beat of reflection.

The scene transitions to a completely different and vibrant landscape of climbing green hills, and once again, the perspective intercuts with the train now laboriously climbing: a boy alongside a buffalo is running a massive, crude grinding wheel, and the train steadily climbs; farmers are diligently working in terraced fields, the train accelerates, climbing faster and faster. Gandhi leans out of a window in a Third Class coach, curiosity piqued. Ahead of him, other passengers are also peering out; some have even jumped down to get a better look. As the train progresses into view, it becomes clear that a military train, consisting of an engine and two cars, has been derailed just ahead of them. A small troop of cavalry is seen slowly making its way along the line of Gandhi’s train toward them. Clearly identifiable as British, their troop leader is visibly and viciously angry, his demeanor fierce.

Nehru takes an iced drink from a servant, and with a wistful shake of his head, observes the unfolding events. As the train passes by the camera, the vantage moves to the Third Class section, which appears to be besieged by a multitude of humanity. People cling desperately to the outside of each door, and many more are seated precariously on the central wooden planks atop the roofs of the two coaches. Gandhi and Charlie are among those riding on the exterior of the coach, hanging on bravely through the door, and they are visibly thrilled by the exhilarating experience. Ba, however, within the jam-packed coach, finds no amusement in the situation. She maintains a firm and unwavering grip on one of Gandhi’s arms, ensuring his safety. The camera, which has been steadily moving in, now jumps to focus closely on Jinnah, capturing his fervent delivery and the palpable impact it has upon the audience. The response from the audience is enthusiastic, erupting with cheers. Around the platform, newspaper cameramen are crowded, eagerly photographing him. From the back of the platform, Patel comes forward, clapping with earnest enthusiasm.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The camera swiftly moves alongside the train as it travels along the river's edge, capturing the sun's reflection glimmering on the train windows. The sun is positioned high in the sky as the train comes to a halt by the river. An English clergyman emerges from the Second Class coaches, cautiously dipping a toe into the water, while children of British enlisted soldiers wade and splash around, their faces glowing with joy. Across the river, near the Third Class coaches, a small group of Indian women squats by the river's edge, engaged in the task of washing clothes. Some of these women carry infants on their backs, while small children stand nearby, observing. Despite their ongoing washing ritual, their attention is drawn to the passengers of the train. Among the Third Class passengers, Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie. Charlie, with his trousers rolled up, engages in a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian boy. Meanwhile, Gandhi holds a large white head cloth, soaking it in the water, but his gaze is captivated by the sight of the women across the river. He notices their emaciated bodies and the clothes they wear, which, upon closer inspection, are nothing more than shredded rags layered upon each other. Gandhi stares at them for a prolonged moment, absorbing the scene. The landscape shifts to climbing green hills, a stark contrast to the previous terrain, and the scene intercuts with the train ascending these hills: a boy and a buffalo operate a massive, crude grinding wheel, and farmers work in terraced fields as the train climbs faster and faster. Gandhi leans out of a window in a Third Class coach, joining other passengers who are also looking ahead; some have even jumped down from the train. As they clear the view, they see a military train consisting of an engine and two cars derailed ahead of them. A small troop of cavalry approaches slowly along the line of Gandhi's train. The cavalry is British, and their troop leader is visibly and viciously angry. Meanwhile, Nehru accepts an iced drink from a servant and shakes his head wistfully. The train continues past the camera to the Third Class section, which appears overwhelmed by the sheer number of people. Passengers cling to the outside of each door, and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches. Gandhi and Charlie are among those riding on the outside of the coach, holding onto the door and thoroughly enjoying the experience. Inside the cramped coach, Ba finds the situation far from amusing as she maintains a firm grip on one of Gandhi's arms. The camera, having been moving in, now cuts to a close shot of Jinnah, intercutting with the fervent impact of his delivery on the audience, who respond with enthusiastic cheers. Newspaper cameramen crowd around the platform, capturing the moment as Patel steps forward from the back of the platform, clapping in support.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The camera follows the train as it races along the river, capturing the sun's reflection on the windows. The train halts by the river, where an English clergyman from the Second Class coaches tests the water with his toe, while children of British soldiers play joyfully. Across the river, Indian women from the Third Class coaches wash clothes, some with infants on their backs, all observing the train passengers. Gandhi, with Ba and Charlie, stands among the Third Class passengers. Charlie, with rolled-up trousers, plays with a local boy, while Gandhi, soaking a head cloth, is struck by the sight of the women in tattered clothes. The scene shifts to green hills as the train climbs, intercut with images of a boy and buffalo operating a grinding wheel and farmers in terraced fields. Gandhi leans out of a Third Class coach window, observing a derailed military train ahead. A British cavalry troop approaches, led by an irate officer. Meanwhile, Nehru, taking an iced drink, shakes his head wistfully. The train passes the camera, revealing the crowded Third Class section, with people clinging to doors and sitting on the roofs. Gandhi and Charlie enjoy riding outside the coach, while Ba, inside the cramped space, holds onto Gandhi's arm, finding the situation less amusing. The camera shifts to Jinnah, capturing his fervent speech and the audience's enthusiastic response, as newspaper cameramen photograph him and Patel applauds from the platform.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The camera races with the train along the river's edge, the reflected sun glimmering on the windows. The sun is high, indicating midday, and the train is stopped by the river, which in this area is known for its fast-flowing current. We see an English clergyman, representative of the British presence in colonial India during the early 20th century, from the Second Class coaches, dipping a toe cautiously into the water, children of some British enlisted soldiers wading, splashing, their faces alight with fun. Across the river, down from the Third Class coaches, where spaces were far less comfortable and more crowded, a small group of Indian women is squatted by the river's edge, washing clothes in a traditional manner. Some carry infants on their backs, showcasing the multitasking nature of their daily lives, and some small children stand near them. Their ritual of washing goes on, but they are all watching the passengers of the train. Gandhi, a key figure in India's struggle for independence, stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class passengers. Charlie, his trousers rolled up, plays a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian boy. Gandhi is holding a large white head cloth, a piece of clothing commonly used for sun protection, which he is soaking in the water, but his eyes have been arrested by the sight of the women across the river. Their bodies are skin and bone, indicative of the widespread poverty that afflicted many Indians under colonial rule. The clothes they wear, which looked normal from a distance, are rags - literally, shredded rags, one hung on another. Gandhi stares for a moment, a long beat. Climbing green hills, indicative of the diverse geography of India, and again we intercut, this time the train climbing: a boy and buffalo running a huge, crude grinding wheel, illustrating traditional agricultural practices; train climbing; farmers in terraced fields, highlighting the ingenuity in dealing with hilly terrain, train climbing faster and faster. Gandhi is leaning out of a window in a Third Class coach. Ahead of him, other passengers are looking too; some have jumped down. As they come clear, they can see that a military train of an engine and two cars has been derailed ahead of them, a frequent occurrence due to the old and poorly maintained tracks during that era. A small troop of cavalry is coming slowly along the line of Gandhi's train toward them. They are British, a common sight as colonial powers maintained heavy military presence, and their troop leader is viciously angry. Nehru, a future Prime Minister of India and a prominent figure in the Indian National Movement, takes an iced drink from a servant, and Nehru shakes his head wistfully, reflecting on the situation. The train passes the camera to the Third Class section, which seems besieged by humanity, an indication of how overcrowded trains were. People cling to the outside of each door and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches. Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the outside of the coach, hanging on through the door, both enjoying it immensely as it symbolizes freedom despite the circumstances. Ba, inside the jammed coach, finds it very unfunny, worried for their safety. She has a grip on one of Gandhi's arms for reassurance. The camera has been moving in; now it jumps to Jinnah, a leader who played a pivotal role in the creation of Pakistan, in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience, who were clearly moved by his words. And the audience cheers him, their enthusiasm palpable. Newspaper cameramen, essential for documenting these historic events, crowded around the platform to photograph him. Patel, another influential figure in Indian politics, comes forward from the back of the platform, clapping in support.

Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the outside of the coach hanging on through the door and both enjoying it immensely. Ba inside the jammed coach finds it very unfunny. She has a grip on one of Gandhi's arms. The camera has been moving in now it jumps to Jinnah in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience. And the audience cheers him. Newspaper cameramen crowded around the platform photograph him. Patel comes forward from the back of the platform clapping.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: The camera races with the train along the river's edge. the reflected sun glimmering on the windows. The sun is high and the train is stopped by the river. We see an English clergyman from the Second Class coaches dipping a toe cautiously into the water. children of some British enlisted soldiers wading splashing faces alight with fun. Across the river down from the Third Class coaches. a small group of Indian women is squatted by the river's edge washing clothes. Some carry infants on their backs and some small children stand near them. Their ritual of washing goes on but they are all watching the passengers of the train. Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class passengers. Charlie his trousers rolled up plays a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian boy. Gandhi is holding a large white head cloth which he is soaking in the water but his eyes have been arrested by the sight of the women across the river. Their bodies are skin and bone. The clothes they wear which looked normal from the distance are rags  literally shredded rags. one hung on another. Gandhi stares for a moment a long beat. Climbing green hills  a totally different terrain  and again we intercut this time the train climbing. a boy and buffalo running a huge crude grinding wheel. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. train climbing farmers in terraced fields. train climbing faster and faster. Gandhi is leaning out of a window in a Third Class coach. Ahead of him. other passengers are looking too. some have jumped down. As they come clear they can see that a military train of an engine and two cars has been derailed ahead of them. A small troop of cavalry is coming slowly along the line of Gandhi's train toward them. They are British and their troop leader is viciously angry. Nehru takes an iced drink from a servant and Nehru shakes his head wistfully. The train passes the camera to the Third Class section which seems besieged by humanity. People cling to the outside of each door and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches. Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the outside of the coach hanging on through the door and both enjoying it immensely. Ba inside the jammed coach finds it very unfunny. She has a grip on one of Gandhi's arms. The camera has been moving in now it jumps to Jinnah in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience. And the audience cheers him. Newspaper cameramen crowded around the platform photograph him. Patel comes forward from the back of the platform clapping.

We see an English clergyman from the Second Class coaches dipping a toe cautiously into the water. children of some British enlisted soldiers wading splashing faces alight with fun. And the audience cheers him. Newspaper cameramen crowded around the platform photograph him. Patel comes forward from the back of the platform clapping.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: The camera races with the train along the river's edge. the reflected sun glimmering on the windows. The sun is high and the train is stopped by the river. We see an English clergyman from the Second Class coaches dipping a toe cautiously into the water. The camera has been moving in now it jumps to Jinnah in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience. And the audience cheers him. Newspaper cameramen crowded around the platform photograph him. Patel comes forward from the back of the platform clapping.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The squirrel races with the train along the river's edge, the reflected sun glimmering on the windows. The moon is high and the train is stopped by the river. We see a penguin from the Second Class coaches, dipping a toe cautiously into the water, children of some British enlisted soldiers wading, splashing, faces alight with fun. Across the river down from the Third Class coaches, a small group of hedgehogs is squatted by the river's edge, washing clothes. Some carry infants on their backs, and some small children stand near them. Their ritual of washing goes on, but they are all watching the passengers of the train. A giraffe stands with a koala and a kangaroo among the Third Class passengers. The kangaroo, his trousers rolled up, plays a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian boy. The giraffe is holding a large white head cloth which it is soaking in the water, but its eyes have been arrested by the sight of the hedgehogs across the river. Their bodies are skin and bone. The clothes they wear, which looked normal from the distance, are rags - literally, shredded rags, one hung on another. The giraffe stares for a moment, a long beat. Climbing green hills - a totally different terrain - and again we intercut, this time the train climbing: a zebra and buffalo running a huge, crude grinding wheel, train climbing; farmers in terraced fields, train climbing faster and faster. The giraffe is leaning out of a window in a Third Class coach. Ahead of it, other passengers are looking too; some have jumped down. As they come clear, they can see that a military train of an engine and two cars has been derailed ahead of them. A small troop of turtles is coming slowly along the line of the giraffe's train toward them. They are British, and their troop leader is viciously angry. An elephant takes an iced drink from a servant, and the elephant shakes its head wistfully. The train passes the kangaroo to the Third Class section, which seems besieged by humanity. People cling to the outside of each door and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches. The giraffe and the koala are riding on the outside of the coach, hanging on through the door, and both enjoying it immensely. A rabbit, inside the jammed coach, finds it very unfunny. It has a grip on one of the giraffe's arms. The kangaroo has been moving in; now it jumps to a lizard in close shot and intercuts with the impact of its fervid delivery on the audience. And the audience cheers it. Newspaper cameramen crowded around the platform photograph it. A cat comes forward from the back of the platform, clapping.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The camera races with the bicycle along the lake's edge, the reflected moon glimmering on the helmets. The moon is high and the bicycle is stopped by the lake. We see an English clergyman from the Second Class cabins, dipping a toe cautiously into the sand, children of some British enlisted soldiers wading, splashing, faces alight with fun. Across the lake down from the Third Class cabins, a small group of Indian women is squatted by the lake's edge, washing vegetables. Some carry kittens on their backs, and some small puppies stand near them. Their ritual of washing goes on, but they are all watching the cyclists. Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class riders. Charlie, his socks rolled up, plays a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian pup. Gandhi is holding a large white towel which he is soaking in the water, but his eyes have been arrested by the sight of the women across the lake. Their bodies are skin and bone. The clothes they wear, which looked normal from the distance, are rags - literally, shredded rags, one hung on another. Gandhi stares for a moment, a long beat. Climbing red dunes - a totally different terrain - and again we intercut, this time the bicycle climbing: a boy and donkey running a huge, crude spinning wheel, bicycle climbing; herders in terraced fields, bicycle climbing faster and faster. Gandhi is leaning out of a window in a Third Class cabin. Ahead of him, other riders are looking too; some have jumped down. As they come clear, they can see that a military cart of a wagon and two trailers has been overturned ahead of them. A small troop of infantry is coming slowly along the line of Gandhi's bicycle toward them. They are British, and their troop leader is viciously angry. Nehru takes an iced treat from a gardener, and Nehru shakes his head wistfully. The bicycle passes the camera to the Third Class section, which seems besieged by humanity. People cling to the outside of each door and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two cabins. Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the outer seats of the cabin, hanging on through the door, and both enjoying it immensely. Ba, inside the jammed cabin, finds it very unfunny. She has a grip on one of Gandhi's arms. The camera has been moving in; now it jumps to Jinnah in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience. And the audience cheers him. Newspaper photographers crowded around the platform capture him. Patel comes forward from the back of the platform, clapping.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The camera dances with the train along the river's edge, the reflected sun shimmering on the windows. The sun is high and the train is parked by the river. We see an English clergyman from the Second Class coaches, tossing a pebble cautiously into the water, children of some British enlisted soldiers skipping, laughing, faces alight with curiosity. Across the river down from the Third Class coaches, a small group of Indian women is perched by the river's edge, singing folk songs. Some carry infants on their backs, and some small children hop near them. Their ritual of singing goes on, but they are all observing the passengers of the train. Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class passengers. Charlie, his trousers rolled up, tries a tentative balancing game with a skinny little Indian boy. Gandhi is holding a large white head cloth which he is folding in the water, but his eyes have been captivated by the sight of the women across the river. Their bodies are skin and bone. The clothes they wear, which looked normal from the distance, are tattered - literally, shredded rags, one hung on another. Gandhi gazes for a moment, a long beat. Climbing green hills - a totally different terrain - and again we intercut, this time the train gliding: a boy and buffalo spinning a huge, crude grinding wheel, train ascending; farmers in terraced fields, train moving faster and faster. Gandhi is leaning out of a window in a Third Class coach. Ahead of him, other passengers are peering too; some have jumped off. As they come clear, they can see that a military train of an engine and two cars has been overturned ahead of them. A small troop of cavalry is approaching slowly along the line of Gandhi's train toward them. They are British, and their troop leader is furiously scolding. Nehru sips an iced drink from a servant, and Nehru nods his head wistfully. The train glides past the camera to the Third Class section, which seems engulfed by humanity. People latch onto the outside of each door and many more are perched on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches. Gandhi and Charlie are clinging on the outside of the coach, gripping through the door, and both relishing it immensely. Ba, inside the cramped coach, finds it very unsettling. She has a hold on one of Gandhi's arms. The camera has been zooming in; now it flashes to Jinnah in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervent delivery on the audience. And the audience applauds him. Newspaper cameramen swarmed around the platform capture him. Patel moves forward from the back of the platform, applauding.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The bicycle zooms with the submarine along the mountain's edge, the reflected moon glimmering on the sails. The moon is low and the submarine is halted by the mountain. We see a French chef from the First Class carriages, dipping a shoulder cautiously into the puddle, cats of some Italian architects wading, splashing, tails alight with joy. Across the mountain up from the Fifth Class carriages, a small band of Canadian fishermen is crouched by the mountain's edge, ironing blankets. Some carry puppies on their heads, and some tiny ducks stand near them. Their ritual of ironing goes on, but they are all watching the crew of the submarine. Einstein stands with Lisa and Max among the Fifth Class sailors. Max, his jacket rolled up, plays a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Canadian girl. Einstein is holding a large orange scarf which he is dipping in the puddle, but his eyes have been caught by the sight of the fishermen across the mountain. Their forms are fluff and feathers. The jackets they wear, which looked ordinary from the distance, are patches - literally, tattered patches, one hung on another. Einstein gazes for a moment, a long pause. Soaring red canyons - a totally different landscape - and again we intercut, this time the submarine climbing: an eagle and camel pulling a massive, simple grinding wheel, submarine climbing; chefs in sloped gardens, submarine climbing faster and faster. Einstein is leaning out of a door in a Fifth Class carriage. Ahead of him, other sailors are watching too; some have leaped down. As they come clear, they can see that a musical train of an orchestra and two flutes has been overturned ahead of them. A small squad of singers is approaching slowly along the line of Einstein's submarine toward them. They are Italian, and their squad conductor is viciously annoyed. Picasso takes a warm soup from a butler, and Picasso shakes his head dreamily. The submarine moves past the bicycle to the Fifth Class section, which seems surrounded by wildlife. Bears cling to the outside of each gate and many more are perched on the central stone beams on the ceilings of the two carriages. Einstein and Max are riding on the exterior of the carriage, hanging on through the window, and both relishing it enormously. Lisa, inside the crowded carriage, finds it very somber. She has a grip on one of Einstein's legs. The bicycle has been rolling in; now it leaps to Tesla in tight shot and intercuts with the effect of his energetic presentation on the orchestra. And the orchestra applauds him. Magazine bakers gathered around the stage sketch him. Curie comes forward from the back of the stage, snapping.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The kite glides with the boat along the canyon's edge, the reflected sun twinkling on the hulls. The moon is high and the boat is moored by the canyon. We observe a French artist from the First Class cabins, gently tapping a paintbrush on the canvas, grandchildren of some American tourists dancing, giggling, faces illuminated with joy. Across the canyon down from the Fourth Class cabins, a small group of Chinese men is crouched by the canyon's edge, arranging stones. Some carry tools in their pockets, and some small animals stand near them. Their chore of arranging continues, but they are all observing the crew of the boat. Lincoln stands with Marilyn and Sherlock among the Fourth Class travelers. Sherlock, his sleeves rolled up, engages in a cautious jumping game with a tiny little Chinese girl. Lincoln is holding a large blue bandana which he is plunging in the paint, but his gaze has been captivated by the sight of the men across the canyon. Their figures are slender and frail. The garments they wear, which seemed typical from afar, are tatters - indeed, frayed tatters, one layered on another. Lincoln gazes for a moment, a prolonged pause. Ascending yellow valleys - an entirely new landscape - and again we intercut, this time the boat ascending: a girl and donkey operating a massive, primitive milling stone, boat ascending; gardeners in stepped orchards, boat ascending swiftly and swiftly. Lincoln is leaning out of a window in a Fourth Class cabin. Before him, other tourists are gazing too; some have clambered up. As they come into view, they can see that a cargo boat of a vessel and three rafts has been capsized ahead of them. A small squad of sailors is coming slowly along the line of Lincoln's boat toward them. They are Italian, and their squad leader is fiercely frustrated. Churchill takes a warm apple pie from a butler, and Churchill nods his head cheerfully. The boat glides past the kite to the Fourth Class area, which seems enveloped by humanity. People cling to the exterior of each hatch and many more are perched on the central metal panels on the roofs of the three cabins. Lincoln and Sherlock are perched on the exterior of the cabin, gripping through the hatch, and both relishing it deeply. Marilyn, inside the cramped cabin, finds it highly disagreeable. She has a clutch on one of Lincoln's legs. The kite has been soaring nearby; now it swoops to Churchill in close view and intercuts with the impact of his zealous presentation on the spectators. And the spectators acclaim him. Television crews clustered around the dock film him. Roosevelt steps forward from the edge of the dock, applauding.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The camera ambles with the bicycle along the forest's edge, the dappled moon casting shadows on the windows. The moon is low and the bicycle is paused by the forest. We see an English baker from the Second Class wagons, tossing a hat leisurely into the air, children of some British naval officers skipping, dancing, faces alight with curiosity. Across the forest down from the Third Class wagons, a small group of Indian men is perched by the forest's edge, knitting hats. Some carry kittens on their backs, and some small puppies stand near them. Their ritual of knitting goes on, but they are all observing the riders of the bicycle. Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class riders. Charlie, his shoes tied up, plays a cautious bouncing game with a chubby little Indian cat. Gandhi is holding a large red umbrella which he is dipping in the air, but his eyes have been captivated by the sight of the men across the forest. Their bodies are lean and strong. The hats they wear, which looked colorful from the distance, are patched - literally, mismatched patches, one sewn on another. Gandhi observes for a moment, a lingering pause. Sprawling golden plains - a totally different environment - and again we intercut, this time the bicycle soaring: a girl and horse jumping a tall, polished fence, bicycle soaring; dancers in crowded squares, bicycle soaring faster and faster. Gandhi is leaning out of a window in a Third Class wagon. Ahead of him, other riders are observing too; some have hopped up. As they come clear, they can see that a naval yacht of a sail and two cabins has been capsized ahead of them. A small group of seagulls is gliding slowly along the line of Gandhi's bicycle toward them. They are British, and their flock leader is surprisingly calm. Nehru takes a warm tea from a friend, and Nehru nods his head thoughtfully. The bicycle ambles past the camera to the Third Class section, which seems encircled by nature. People cling to the outside of each fence and many more are seated on the central stone benches on the roofs of the two wagons. Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the outside of the wagon, hanging on through the window, and both relishing it immensely. Ba, inside the crowded wagon, finds it very tedious. She has a hold on one of Gandhi's legs. The camera has been wandering in; now it shifts to Jinnah in close view and intercuts with the resonance of his passionate gesture on the assembly. And the assembly applauds him. Magazine illustrators crowded around the gazebo sketch him. Patel approaches from the corner of the gazebo, grinning.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The kite zooms with the bicycle along the mountain's base, the reflected moon shimmering on the glasses. The moon is low and the bicycle is parked by the desert. We observe an American sailor from the Third Floor apartments, nudging a nose daringly into the sand, birds of some Australian artists flying, diving, wings aglow with joy. Across the desert down from the Fourth Floor apartments, a small assembly of Japanese men is perched by the mountain's base, carving pumpkins. Some hold kittens on their shoulders, and some tiny lizards crawl near them. Their routine of carving goes on, but they are all observing the animals of the bicycle. Mozart stands with Ada and Sam among the Fourth Floor tenants. Sam, his hat tipped down, plays a daring gliding game with a chubby little Japanese cat. Mozart is holding a large red scarf which he is soaking in the sand, but his eyes have been arrested by the view of the men across the desert. Their figures are muscle and sinew. The shoes they wear, which appeared normal from the distance, are scraps - literally, tattered scraps, one resting on another. Mozart gazes for a moment, a lengthy pause. Towering red cliffs - a completely different environment - and again we intercut, this time the bicycle ascending: a girl and donkey pulling a giant, intricate weaving loom, bicycle ascending; bakers in stepped gardens, bicycle ascending slower and slower. Mozart is peering out of a balcony in a Fourth Floor unit. Beside him, other tenants are staring too; some have leapt up. As they come clear, they can see that a merchant cart of a wagon and three mules has been overturned beside them. A small band of drummers is marching quickly along the edge of Mozart's bicycle toward them. They are French, and their band leader is extremely pleased. Picasso takes a warm meal from a chef, and Picasso shakes his head merrily. The bicycle passes the kite to the Fourth Floor section, which seems surrounded by nature. Animals cling to the side of each handle and many more are standing on the central wooden beams on the tops of the three units. Mozart and Sam are swinging on the side of the unit, gripping through the handle, and both relishing it greatly. Ada, outside the crowded unit, finds it very unamusing. She has a hold on one of Mozart's legs. The kite has been drifting in; now it skips to Tesla in distant shot and interacts with the effect of his melodic speech on the spectators. And the spectators applaud him. Cartoonists gathered around the rooftop sketch him. Poe comes forward from the front of the rooftop, laughing.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The camera follows a train by the river, where an English clergyman and soldier's children enjoy the water. Nearby, Indian women wash clothes, watched by Gandhi, who notices their poverty. As the train climbs hills, Gandhi leans out from a Third Class coach with passengers spotting a derailed military train. British cavalry approaches with an angry leader. Nehru watches the scene, shaking his head. The train continues, crowded with passengers clinging to doors and roofs. Gandhi and Charlie ride outside, having fun, while Ba, inside, disapproves, holding Gandhi's arm. The scene shifts to Jinnah passionately addressing an excited audience, with Patel applauding him from the platform.

coach finds it very unfunny  other passengers are looking too  Charlie his trousers rolled up plays a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian boy  Some carry infants on their backs and some small children stand near them  She has a grip on one of Gandhi's arms  A small troop of cavalry is coming slowly along the line of Gandhi's train toward them  children of some British enlisted soldiers wading splashing faces alight with fun  And the audience cheers him  The camera races with the train along the river's edge  some have jumped down  Gandhi stares for a moment a long beat  Gandhi is leaning out of a window in a Third Class coach  Climbing green hills  a totally different terrain  and again we intercut this time the train climbing  They are British and their troop leader is viciously angry  Newspaper cameramen crowded around the platform photograph him  The camera has been moving in now it jumps to Jinnah in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience  The sun is high and the train is stopped by the river  Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the outside of the coach hanging on through the door and both enjoying it immensely  People cling to the outside of each door and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches  Patel comes forward from the back of the platform clapping one hung on another  the reflected sun glimmering on the windows  Their ritual of washing goes on but they are all watching the passengers of the train  train climbing faster and faster  The train passes the camera to the Third Class section which seems besieged by humanity  Nehru takes an iced drink from a servant and Nehru shakes his head wistfully  Gandhi is holding a large white head cloth which he is soaking in the water but his eyes have been arrested by the sight of the women across the river  We see an English clergyman from the Second Class coaches dipping a toe cautiously into the water  Their bodies are skin and bone  Across the river down from the Third Class coaches  a small group of Indian women is squatted by the river's edge washing clothes  Ahead of him  The clothes they wear which looked normal from the distance are rags  literally shredded rags  Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class passengers  a boy and buffalo running a huge crude grinding wheel

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: train climbing faster and faster  Gandhi is leaning out of a window in a Third Class coach  Ahead of him  other passengers are looking too  some have jumped down  As they come clear they can see that a military train of an engine and two cars has been derailed ahead of them  A small troop of cavalry is coming slowly along the line of Gandhi's train toward them  They are British and their troop leader is viciously angry  Nehru takes an iced drink from a servant and Nehru shakes his head wistfully  The train passes the camera to the Third Class section which seems besieged by humanity  People cling to the outside of each door and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches  Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the outside of the coach hanging on through the door and both enjoying it immensely  Ba inside the jammed coach finds it very unfunny  She has a grip on one of Gandhi's arms  The camera has been moving in now it jumps to Jinnah in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience  And the audience cheers him  Newspaper cameramen crowded around the platform photograph him  Patel comes forward from the back of the platform clapping The camera races with the train along the river's edge  the reflected sun glimmering on the windows  The sun is high and the train is stopped by the river  We see an English clergyman from the Second Class coaches dipping a toe cautiously into the water  children of some British enlisted soldiers wading splashing faces alight with fun  Across the river down from the Third Class coaches  a small group of Indian women is squatted by the river's edge washing clothes  Some carry infants on their backs and some small children stand near them  Their ritual of washing goes on but they are all watching the passengers of the train  Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class passengers  Charlie his trousers rolled up plays a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian boy  Gandhi is holding a large white head cloth which he is soaking in the water but his eyes have been arrested by the sight of the women across the river  Their bodies are skin and bone  The clothes they wear which looked normal from the distance are rags  literally shredded rags  one hung on another  Gandhi stares for a moment a long beat  Climbing green hills  a totally different terrain  and again we intercut this time the train climbing  a boy and buffalo running a huge crude grinding wheel  train climbing farmers in terraced fields
